DIV1.P: As it is acted by HIS MAJESTY'S SERVANTS, AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.
DUBLIN: Printed for J. HOEY, Sen. P. and W. WILSON, J. EXSHAW, H. SAUNDERS, B. GRIERSON, J. POTTS, D. CHAMBERLAINE, W. SLEATER, L. FLIN, J. SHEPPARD, J. WILLIAMS, and W. COLLES, M, DCC, LXVIII.

DIV1.HEAD: TO MR. KING.
DIV1.P: IT was a custom with the Grecian Fishermen of old, when they had escaped an danger at sea, to dedi∣cate their little skiffs to whatever Tutelary Being they attributed its preservation; there is nothing more cer∣tain, than that the ABSENT MAN is chiefly, was I not the Author myself, perhaps, I might say wholly, indebted for its success, to your excellent performance; it is therefore, with great pleasure I take this method of expressing my obligations to you.

Indeed, when I consider your punctuality in attending the Rehearsals of this little Piece, though out of the common business of the Theatre; and the care you took, not only to be perfect yourself, but that it should be, in every respect, produced as complete as possible; I can∣not help congratulating all our present Writers for the Stage, on the acquisition of a performer of such uncom∣mon merit; and so great a favourite with the Public; who, they may be assured, will consider their advantage and reputation, as well as his own; and do their pieces, at least, all the justice they are capable of receiving.

Had I an inclination to indulge myself in the Dedica∣tory Stile. I might now tell you, with truth, that few men have filled so many Characters with the same pro∣priety that you have; but I leave this to some News∣paper Essayist, who may be fond of playing upon mean∣ings and wos; and vary your appearance upon the Theatre how you please, I will venture to say, your acquaintance in private life, will always find you an honest and sensible, and a gentleman like man.

CLOSER.SALUTE: I am, Sir, with great esteem, your obliged, humble servant.

DIV1.HEAD: PREFACE.
DIV1.P: THIS farce was written some years ago, since which time it has lain by the Author, without being offered to the stage; nor should he have ventured it there at all, but to serve Mr. Holland, at his benefit; upon which occasion, he thought the Publick, through favour to so deserving a performer, would be willing to be pleased with any thing.
The event has greatly exceeded his hopes; the farce was not only received with general approbation the first night, but that sort of approbation which a writer may depend upon with greatest safety.

Q.L: "For smiles are honest when the hands are not;"

DIV1.P: And on the second night, it met with marks of fa∣vour still more manifest; this engaged the author to look over it with greater care than he had before done, and having heightened some places where he thought it most deficient, he now submits it to the public, in a form, in which, he hopes it will not utterly displease, though it is needless to say that things of this kind have their principal merit in representation.

Regnard one of the most famous French comic poets, ranked by his countrymen next to Moliere, has written a play of five acts upon this subject, called, le DIS∣TRAIT; however, exclusive of their great disparity in merit; no two pieces can be less alike than that, and the ABSENT MAN; at least, where the materials have been drawn from the same source. The DISTRAIT of Regnard is exactly the Menalcas of La Bruyere's charac∣ters, a few things only left out, which, though possessed of a pleasant extravagance in recital▪ would be too absurd for actual representation; the hint of the ABSENT MAN, and no more, is taken from the same character of Menalcas, translated in one of the num∣bers of the Spectator; with the assistance of which, if the present writer has been able to produce a laughable farce, it is all he aimed at, and he pretends to no more praise than such a trifling composition may deserve.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.BYLINE: Written by the AUTHOR of the FARCE.

LG.L: ERE the curtain draws up, list a little to me:
Are you all in a very good humour? Let's see;
Good humour you have, howe'er you come by it,
And I'm glad to my soul; for, by Jove we shall try it.
Our farce is so very a farce, I'm in doubt,
If the pit and the boxes; will suffer it out;
But when we're in danger of such a mishap,
My dear friends above, drown their hiss in a clap;
And if you are pleas'd with our farcical man,
In spite of their airs, laugh as loud as you can.
To give you a sketch, now, by way of portraying,
His character's this—pray observe what I'm saying;
An odd kind of whimsical blundering being,
Who has ears without hearing, and eyes without seeing;
Takes things by all handles, except by the right,
Ask a question in black, he answers in white.
Yes for no, no for yes; confuses, mistakes;
All he does so like dreaming▪ you'd scarce think he wakes.
Suppose to back-gammon my gentleman falls,
Box and dice in his hand▪ for some water he calls;
'Tis brought in a tumbler, when pop, in a trice,
He throws out the liquor, and swallows the dice.
Hard set are poor bards for your pleasure to cater,
And thus one provides for you, from the Spectator;
From volume the first, page three hundred and nine,
Number seventy-seven he takes his design;
Let that be his sanction for what you behold▪
Can the figure be bad from so perfect a mold?
'Tis polish'd and varnish'd as well as he's able,
And he hopes you'll find something like conduct and fable.
Yet still this curst absence—in shortt here's the thing,
If the character hits, thence his actions all spring;
And nought will disgust you, and nought will alarm you,
You'll taste ev'ry blunder, is follies will charm you;
But if—Gad we're all in a terrible fright,
So, begging for mercy, I wish you good night.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: SHATTERBRAIN'S Lodgings. A Dressing-Table, with a Glass, &c. FRANK asleep in a Chair. LANDLADY enters in a hurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: MR. Frank—Mr. Frank!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Rouse, rouse, man.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Is my master come home?

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Your master come home! no, he's not—but there's the Doctor below in his chariot, come to carry him to his bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Yaw—have I slept long?

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: You are asleep still, one would think—I tell you there's your master's father-in-law that is to be, come to fetch him away.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: My Master's father-in-law that is to be, come to fetch him away!

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Ay.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Well—what shall we do?

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Nay, I don't know—I come to ask you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: If I was not acquainted with my master now, I should naturally conclude that he had either hanged, or drown'd himself, in order to avoid being married.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Oh, he's a sad gentleman!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: He is a little out of the way sometimes, indeed▪

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: But the Doctor waits—what excuse will you make him.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why, none—I remember it was a maxim, with an attorney I once served, always to tell the truth—when a lye could not serve his purpose bet∣ter—and I think we must e'en follow his example, at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Then I'll run down again, tho' I make a strange dirty figure. (Looking at herself in the Glass.) Lord! how I'm alter'd within these twelve years.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I will but rub my eyes, and follow you.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: Frank standing silent for some time, he fals into an im∣moderate fit of Laughter.
DIV2.P: Well, if ever I (Laughs again.) If ever I heard the like of this since I was born, I wish I may be mar∣ried to a woman of three-score, with the constitution of a girl of sixteen—Why it will be the general joke of the whole town—that a man, (Laughs again) that a man should be such a—but stay—I'll tell the story to myself, and try how it will sound—Doctor Gruel, a physician of noted worth and eminence, comes to a certain gentleman, Mr. Shatterbrain by name; and on account of an antient friendship subsisting between their families, and for some other reasons, which shall be nameless, offers him his only daughter for a wife—Mr. Shatterbrain accepts the propo∣sal, and, in short, the happy day arrives, in which he is to be put in possession of the amiable object; when, behold you, the Doctor coming to call on his de∣stined son-in-law, presto, pass and be gone, the bird is flown; my gentleman is not to be found—He took himself off the same morning about seven o'Clock—and nobody can tell what is become of him—it will never do—But, hark! the Doctor is marching up stairs—perhaps he may be able to give a physical reason for this.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: FRANK, DOCTOR GRUEL, LANDLADY.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: So young man, where's your master?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Really, Sir, I don't know.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: When will he come in?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Upon my word, Sir, I can't tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Did he say nothing to you when he was going out?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Not a syllable, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Nor to you, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Nor to me, Sir, as I'm a christian.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Mercy on us; I suppose you know what engagements he had upon his hands this evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Yes, sure, Sir, very well, and I thought he had known it himself; but it seems I was mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Seriously, I am afraid some accident has happened to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: No, Sir, I don't believe any accident has happened to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Nor I neither, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: What's your opinion then?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I believe I need not tell you, Sir, that my master is, one or other, the most absent man this day upon the face of the earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Truly, I have often heard him remarked for it; nay, I have myself taken notice of several glaring instances of it in him; but, that is a failing he will soon get the better of when his thoughts are pro∣perly employed; and matrimony—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Will in all likelihood perfectly cure him. 'Tis granted, Sir, matrimony is without doubt an excellent remedy, in such distempers; a kind of manna and cream of tartar; a mixture of sweet and sower; wonderfully adapted to purge the mind of it's gross humours, and reduce the understanding to a perfect regularity of constitution.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: A good comical fellow this.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: But you cannot expect that the patient should recover, Sir, before you have administer'd the remedy you intend to prescribe for his disease: there∣fore, you must not be surprised if my master happens to labour under a very violent fit of his out of the way malady, at this present moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: How do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Neither more, nor less, than that he has forgot he was to be married to your daughter to night, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Forgot.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: As sure as can be he has Doctor.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Ay, Sir, forgot—and given the reins to his wild imagination, suffer'd it to run away with him the Lord knows whither. Why, Sir, when he is in the forgetting mood, his memory is a perfect sieve—Any thing will fall thro' it—I have known him forget his own name before now.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P:
I am unwilling to think my friend Shatter∣brain design'd to affront me—But if his memory was a sieve, to which you compare it, that only
yields a passage to minuter particle, while the more gross remain behind—And an affair of con∣sequence, like—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Lord, Sir! I could tell you such stories of him, as would make you credit this with very little difficulty—for instance, the other day▪ he was sit∣ting in a coffee-house, when a fly which had buzz'd about him a good while, and he was watching an ∣portunity to kill, unluckily settled upon the cheek of a person who stood near him—Ha! says he, I believe I have you now; and with that, Sir, he up with his hand, and hit the poor gentleman such a confounded slap, as made the room ring again; one started, the other stared; in short, swords were drawn, and the case would insallibly have been transferred to Hyde Park, had not the acquaintance on both sides interposed; so he begged pardon, confessed he did not know what he was doing; it ended in a hearty laugh, and the general astonishment of the whole company.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: About a fortnight ago, Sir, he locked up a lady, and a gentleman, in his bed-chamber here, in the way of a joke only; was call'd down about some business; forgot it by the time he came to the foot of the stairs, went out with the key in his pocket, and it was six o'clock before we could set the pound∣ed couple at liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: His ideas are so confused, sometimes, Sir, that I have known him write a letter to one person, direct it to another, and send it to a third, who could not devise who it came from; because, he had forgot to put his name to the bottom on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: A beggar takes off his hat to him in the street, in hopes of receiving an alms; Mr. Shatter∣brain makes him a low bow, tells him, he's his most obedient humble servant, and walks on.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P:
But the best thing I have heard of him a good while, was, what he did lately at a gentleman's house in the city; where taking his leave with an intention to go away, in one of his absent sits, he mounted up three pair of stairs into the garet; the maids that by chance were ironing there▪ wonder'd what the plague kept such a stamping about the
rooms, when one of them taking a candle to see what it was, found my poor master; who, in the utmost confusion, told her▪ he fancy'd he had made some mistake, and begg'd to know if that was not the way to the street door.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Well, I don't know; but, if his present behaviour proceeds from his forgetfulness, it is the most extraordinary instance of the kind that ever was heard of; and, how shall I proceed in this case; my daughter is at home ready dressed; the lawyer will be there presently with the writings; I have taken out a lience; appointed the clergyman to come and marry them; how shall I put it off after this, with∣out making us all ridiculous?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: 'Tis very true, Sir, I am sure I have been at my wits end about it all day.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Suppose, Mr. Frank, you were to go and look for your master again; what if you gave a peep into the Bedford coffee-house?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Shall I, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: If you think you will find him there.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: It can be no harm to try, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Very well, I'll wait for you; go, and make what haste you can.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: DOCTOR GRUEL, LANDLADY.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: I hope he may find him.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: So do I with all my heart; for, on many accounts, I would not wish to have my daughter's marriage delay'd; her own indiscretion, Madam, has occasioned me to treat her with a severity of late, very irksome both to herself and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: That's a pity, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doct.
SP.P: In truth and so it is: few fathers have taken greater care in the education of a child, nor has that care been wholly unprofitable; for I think I may say without vanity, that there is not a young woman in England, of her age and station, more compleatly ac∣complished than my Flavia.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: And yet she has no more pride, I warrant, than a boarding-school girl, in the first row of her samplar.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P:
That's her fault, Madam—a proper pride is
woman's virtue—I should be sorry to see my daugh∣ter give herself airs, but at the same time I would have her know her proper value; I would not have her throw herself away.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: No, to be sure, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: And yet had I not interposed my parental au∣thority, such was her purpose, Madam; if I may call it throwing herself away, to marry a young fel∣low not worth a groat.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: DOCTOR GRUEL. LANDLADY, FRANK out of breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: My Master's coming, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: As I'm a Christian, I'm glad on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Where did you meet him?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I met him. Sir—O Lord—I met him at the end of the street, Sir—where he has been Heaven knows, but such a figure—So, Sir, I told him I had been in search after him all day, and how you were waiting here—but if I had snapped a pistol at his breast, it could not have put him in greater conster∣nation—he took to his heels, directly, like a madman; and I have almost run myself breathless in order to get home before him, and bring the tidings to your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Why, this is as it should be, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Ay, ay, Sir, all's right again—but I hear Mr. Shatterbrain coming up, so I'll take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: I wish you a good evening; we shall hear now what this whimsical gentleman will have to say for himself.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV2.STAGE: DOCTOR GRUEL, FRANK, SHATTERBRAIN.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Come, my things, to dress quickly—my things to dress—Doctor Gruel your most obedient humble servant—I beg ten thousand pardons, but I'll be ready to wait on you immediately—Frank, why don't you make haste?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I am making all the haste I can, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Time enough, time enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, your mother's very well?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: My mother! Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I hope she is—a—

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: I hope she is happy, Mr. Shatterbrain—Poor woman, she has been dead these nine years—but I believe you mean to ask me for my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: For your daughter! Upon my word, and so I do—bless my soul, what was I thinking of. Did I say your mother? No, no; your daughter to be sure. How does Miss Gruel, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Very well, at your service heartily—if you recollect we agreed to consummate our affairs this evening. Accordingly I have disposed every thing for that purpose; and having a patient to visit in your neighbourhood here, called in my return home to take you along with me—guess then how I was sur∣prised when the people told me you had gone out early, and nobody knew whither.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Really, Sir, I am quite ashamed—but up∣on my word it went out of my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Why, so your servant said he was sure it had, and I am very well pleased to find he was not mistaken—for in truth I was apprehensive that it pro∣ceeded from a worse cause▪ and some ill accident de∣tain'd you—but where the duce have you been with your shoes and stockings?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Frank, what are you doing? my shoes and stockings, Sir? Why they are in a very beastly pickle, that's the truth on't—and now I look at them again, upon my soul I am amazed how I could contrive to make them so though the roads were confounded deep; and if they had been a fathom, it would have been just the same—for I never pick my steps, but wade through the middle of every thing—I had like to have been run over once or twice.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Then you walked into the country?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Faith, Sir, I had no thoughts of it when I left home—but I don't know how it was, the beauty of the weather had inticed me as far as Put∣ney, before I perceived that I was on t'other side the river; where meeting with a party of friends going to dine at Richmond, I made a fifth in their ve∣hicle—by the way I was obliged to get one of the ladies to pay my reckoning—for when I came to put my hand in my pocket—the duce a farthing had I about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: No, that I will answer for—here is your purse, Sir, you left it on the hall table, last night, when you were discharging the chairmen—and 'twas very well I went down as I did, or ten to one but some∣body might have whipped it away.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Which would have been a loss to me, I see—tho' I don't know how much was in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: But did not you talk of dressing? If you have any such intention, you had better do it spee∣dily, and as you will be some little time about it, I will make use of the opportunity to dispatch a few visits, which I must necessarily make this afternoon—you will come as soon as you are ready—and believe me, when I assure you, I long to see you one of my family.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VI.
DIV2.STAGE: SHATTERBRAIN, FRANK.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: By dad, Sir, we had like to have been all to pieces here—I believe the Doctor thought you had gi∣ven him the slip, and that you would not take the goods off his hands, after you had bargained for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Very well he might think so—and you Mr. Dunderpate, when you knew how my affairs were cir∣cumstanced, why did not you put me in mind?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Because, Sir, I thought—

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Because you always think wrong, Sir—Was there any one to enquire for me here to-day?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, Mr. Welldon was here five or six times.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Welldon!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I believe he is but just come to town, Sir, for he had his boots on—he said he'd call again.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: If he should, let him know I shall be glad to see him at Doctor Gruel's, which will be my place of residence henceforward. (After picking his teeth, in a negligent manner while Frank seems to put his things in order.) Well! upon my soul, Mrs. Junket is a very agreeable woman, and so is her friend, Miss Frolick. I have not spent a day more pleasantly a great while—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P:
Was your honour with those ladies to-day then? I saw them go by in a coach and four, with Captain Slang, and Mr. Coxcomb—But let me look at you a little, Sir—if I may be so bold as to ask the
question, pray do you intend to salute this young lady, this evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: What would the puppy be at?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Because, Sir, if your mind is bent that way—I would beg leave to salute you first with my razor—odds bobs, if you should attempt to go near her with that bristly beard!—

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Give me my cap,

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Now, if you'll sit down, Sir, and let me put this cloth about you; I'll make your chin as smooth as the surface of owling▪green in a twinkling—(Shatterbrain sits down to be shaved; Frank puts on the shaving cloth. Shatterbrain talking while the▪servant lathers him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Apropos, Frank, cou'd you ever learn where I lost my boot, the last day I was out a riding?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Lord, Sir, how should I learn, I never heard of such a thing in my life!

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: I have been thinking with myself that one of the fellows at the livery stable must have stole it from me, as I was getting off the horse—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: It's well your legs are not loose, we should soon have you reduced to your stumps. [aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Whu, Whu.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Consider what I'm doing, Sir! If you whistle I shall cut you.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Cut me! 'Sdeath that razor is fit to cut nothing but deal-boards; 'tis a perfect saw: change it directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I will, Sir, I will.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VII.
DIV2.STAGE: SHATTERBRAIN, FRANK, WELLDON.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: My dear Welldon ten thousand welcomes.
SP.STAGE: (Shatterbrain, forgetting the condition he is in, rises with the cloth about him, and runs and salutes Welldon on both sides the face)
SP.P: My fellow tells me you have design'd me this favour two or three times to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I have call'd here more than once, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Because you had any particular commands for me, or only en passent?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Oh, no very particular commands—But I seem to have broke in upon you abruptly.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: My friends can never do so, Sir, though I must own I could wish you had timed your visit a little better; for such is the malignity of my stars, that I cannot at present stay to enjoy the benefit of it.—I must leave you, my boy, and I will give you half an hour to guess the occasion, which forces me to do a thing, otherwise so repugnant to my inclinations.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I am the worst diviner in the world; I cannot even draw consequences.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Then, without farther circumlocution, Sir,—I am going to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Married!

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: (Taking out his snuff-box) The Devil take me but I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Then my intelligence is just, and all my fears are true.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Do you ever take snuff?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Confusion!

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Hey—you Sir—Frank—What have you done to my snuff, blockhead? 'tis wet, and smells of soap.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Wet, and smells of soap, Sir!—Well it may; is not your face all over lather? Sure I had but just be∣gan to shave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Oh, follow me into the next room, and make an end of it. You'll excuse my taking this liberty.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV2.STAGE: WELLDON and afterwards FRANK.
DIV2.P: Pray make no apologies—Unkind Flavia—but why do I upbraid her with unkindness▪ who may possibly be in equal distress with myself?—If I can't prevent the match, it were better almost that I had got no in∣telligence of it—Yet he seems to be ignorant that I am his rival, and I will flatter myself that my good genius has brought me here thus critically, to sound the whole truth of the affair; and by some unforeseen means or other, make me instrumental to the advancement of my own happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Mr. Welldon! what's the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: But I deserve it all—Oh, Frank, how shall I tell you!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Out with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Your master is going to be married to the only woman upon earth that can make me happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Tol lol lol lol.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: 'Tis true, by Heavens—I am his rival—and if you don't assist me—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: (Looking very gravely in his face.) What a strange and unaccountable thing is love—which like an inundation, turns every thing that stands in its way topsy turvy—Misleads the judgment—blinds the understand∣ing—and, from reasonable creatures, leaves us little bet∣ter than whimpering ideots—The strongest it overpowers—the most wary it circumvents—it smarts the wise man—and it tickles the fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: What nonsense is this!—Do you laugh at me?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: 'Fore Cupid not I, Sir—But how, in the name of common sense, can you imagine that I should be able to assist you?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I don't know—I'm almost mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: So one would think—But if this young lady makes such tearing work in your heart, 'tis seven or eight days since her father offered her to my master—what have you been doing all this time?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Nothing—In daily expectation of receiving a letter from her, I never dreamt of any thing of this kind, till a friend writ me word he heard such a report; upon which, I immediately took horse, and judging, that all access would be denied me at Doctor Gruel's, came here the moment I got my foot out of the stirrup.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: And to what purpose?—You did not suppose that my master would give her up to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I supposed he should; nay, and I swear he shall give her up to me—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Fair and softly, good Sir—What would you say now if I should tell you, that this match is made up with the young lady's own consent; and that she likes Mr. Shatterbrain better than you?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Impossible!—If there be any such thing as faith or constancy in woman. But I'll know the truth of that presently—I'll go to her father's house; by some means or other get admittance; and, if I find her false—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P:
You'll go hang yourself in your garters; a very heroic revenge truly!—Well I shall not mention a
word to my master of what you have told me—but mum.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IX.
DIV2.STAGE: WELLDON, FRANK, SHATTERBRAIN.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Frank, where is my sword?—I have been looking for it all over the next room, and can't find it.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Your sword, Sir!—Your sword (looking about for it) Why it hung in the next chamber, behind the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Oh, it hung, it hung—you are the most careless fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why I'm very sure, Sir, I did not—(Looking about) Lord, is not that it in your hand, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Ha! upon my soul it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Shatterbrain, I'll take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Why in such a hurry?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: I have some particular business—and shall but detain you.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Nay if you have business—But, I hope, I shall have the pleasure of seeing you when I can enjoy your company longer, and entertain you better.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: You may depend upon it—the pleasure will be to myself.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE X.
DIV2.STAGE: FRANK, SHATTERBRAIN.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Come, for Heav'n's sake, Sir, get yourself away; the Doctor will imagine you have forgot again.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Is there a chair at the door?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: There's always half a score standing at the next coffee▪house.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Well, the boy below will get me one. Do you take care of the things in the next room: and, d'ye hear—what was I going to say?—Bring my night∣gown and slippers to Doctor Gruel's precisely at ten.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I'll take care, Sir. (Frank goes out, and Shatterbrain takes his hat from the table as if going out too, but suddenly stops at the door.)

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Frank, Frank.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: (Within.) Here, Sir, coming, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Frank, why don't you make haste, Frank?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: (Entering) What do you want, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter
SP.P: Nothing. (Exit with his bat over his night cap.)

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Hey▪ Sir, Master, Mr. Shatterbrain.—One would think the absent Devil had possessed me, as well as him—Ho, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: (Returning.) What ails the fellow? What do you bawl so for?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Your wig, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter
SP.P: Well, Sir, and could you not say so, without making a noise as if the house was on fire? Give it me.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XI.
DIV2.STAGE: FRANK, LANDLADY.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Thanks to providence, he's gone at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: At last, indeed! (A violent knocking at the door.)

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Hey day! Who have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Lord be merciful to me, I'm sure no such vi∣sitors come to me. (Knocking again.) Again—Why, Sally Susan! Are you all deaf. One had need to keep porter at this rate.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: By the impudence of this rap now, it should be either a person of quality or a dun. Who is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: (Having gone to the door) I can't tell; there's whole coach full enquiring for your master.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: My master!

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: See, if they are not coming out!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Let me look—The people he dined with at Richmond, by the mackins.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: What do they want here, I wonder!

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XII.
DIV2.STAGE: MRS. JUNKET, MISS FROLICK, SLANG, COXCOMB, the Company enter laughing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Jun.
SP.P: But where's Shattebrain?—I want him to pay me my two and twenty shillings: Shatterbrain, you poor brute, where are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: Mr Shatterbrain.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: Mr. Shatterbrain.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: Hilloa, ho, ho.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Suppose, Sir, you were to inform your master that we are here.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: My master is not at home, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Not at home!

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: What will you do now?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: Why he left us as soon as he eat his dinner, with an intent of coming home directly. If he is no better a walker, he might as well have stay'd for the coach.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: And yet I thought he set out at a good round pace too.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: I take my death this is very pretty; I wonder we did not pass him on the road!—But he is such a strange creature! I'll be hang'd if he has not gone some round-about way.—I wish now we had not been in such a hurry to leave Richmond, for ten to one whether he'll be in this half hour

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: And all that time we shall have nothing to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Here's four of us; what if we sat down to a game at cards? 'twill serve to amuse us a little, and I want to win some money—Your master has in∣vited us to supper, Sir, so since he is not come in yet, if you'll set the card-table, and get a couple of packs of cards, we'll play a game or two till he does—Heigh ho!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Madam!—Invited them to supper!

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Oh crimine!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: My master has been at home, Madam, and is gone out again for the remainder of the night.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: A fair hum, by the Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: Is not this high?

SP.SPEAKER: Mis Frolick.
SP.P: Vastly high, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: I am at a loss what to make on't.—You know where he is gone, I presume?

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, he's gone to be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: This is better and better.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: 'Tis something funny, faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang
SP.P: I wish, however, he had omitted the jest of asking us to supper.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Nay, Sir, don't be angry with him. I'll be sworn he did not think of it then—The Doctor came for him himself—He has but just left the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Jun.
SP.P: Hist—What Doctor came here for him?

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: Doctor Gruel, Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P:
Whose daughter he is gone to be mar∣ried to, depend upon't. I heard something of this
before—Frolick, do you remember a letter I read you some time ago concerning a certain relation of mine and Flavia Gruel? Perhaps one of you may know him, Billy Welldon.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: Yes, I have seen him about the Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: 'Tis scarce a month since he was within a kiss of snapping up this girl—Poor fellow, I wish he had got her—But her old father is such a—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: Oh, an old hunks! and loves money by all accounts.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Junk.
SP.P: By the way, I could put you in a method of playing a charming trick—What if we were to follow Shatterbrain to Doctor Gruel's?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: An admirable project.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: But of your own proposing, ladies, remember that.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: Damn me, I'll do any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Junk.
SP.P: Give me your hand then—This will be serving Shatterbrain right for the manner he has treated us. Besides, I owe the Doctor a grudge on my cousin's account, and I know it will fret his guts to fiddle strings. Frolick, what do you think of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Frolick.
SP.P: It diverts me of all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Junk.
SP.P: She and I are very intimate there—But what do we stay for?—follow your leader.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: Madam, will you do me the honour of your little finger?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: Heavens! don't hurry one so—(Treading on er toes, as they go out she pushes him.) Oh, you devil, you have kill'd my corns.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XIII.
DIV2.STAGE: FRANK and LANDLADY.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Oh, the devil break your neck—And have you not done a very pretty spot of work here?—I shall be afraid to see my master's face now; to be sure he'll lay all the blame of this upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Land.
SP.P: No, no; if there be any words about it, I'll take the fault upon myself. Will you step into the parlour, and drink a dish of tea? and afterwards we'll have a game at Pam Loo: there's cousin Spriggins, and Mrs. Allum, the Baker's wife, at next door. You know I won four-pence halfpenny from you last night, and I'll give you your revenge—

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Psha, rot my revenge—I shall be played the mischief with, and all because you could not keep your tongue within your teeth.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: Changes to an Antichamber in Dr. GRUEL'S House.
WELDON, ROBIN.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Pray now, Sir, walk softly; can't you tread upon your tip-toes as I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon
SP.P: My honest little lad, I tread as softly as ever I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Did you scrape your shoes before you came up?

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: If the old codger should come now!—we expects him every minute—'Ecod I would not for six∣pence, so I would not—If he did, and knew I let you in, he'd lick me to pieces

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: Never fear—But you have one nothing, after all, without you procure me a sight of Miss Flavia.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: Without you procure me a sight of Miss Flavia, I say, you might as well have left me standing in the street still.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Oh, faith, I can't.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: Try.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: I can't, as I hope to be saved.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: What did you think I wanted to come into the house for then?

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Nay, I did not know; I thought you only wanted to come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: Psha!

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Why, 'tis true; you did not say nothing a∣bout wanting to see Miss Flavia: besides, she has com∣pany with her: and I could tell you a secret, so I could, if you'd swear you would not mention it.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: I won't, upon honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: She's to be married to night, then; master's gone for her husband and the parson.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: I'll tell you what, Robin, if you'll contrive to let Miss Flavia know, that I am here, and would be glad to speak with her, I'll give you this half-crown.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: No, but you won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: Take it, and put it in your pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Give me your hand—Odds bobs, you're a rare fellow. Stay here, I am just going to carry in the tea; I'll give her a sly pinch, and bring her out to you directly.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: WELLDON, then ROBIN, who runs across the Stage, and FLAVIA, who follows him.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: Thus far I have ucceeded then, to the ut∣most bounds of my wishes; and, if I can but go on with equal success—

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Somebody wants me! Oh heavens! Mr. Welldon!

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: You wonder to see me—Perhaps you are displeas'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Not so; and yet, every thing consider'd, I don't know whether I have not reason—What brought you to town, and how did you gain admittance here?

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: I have no time to answer such superfluous questions; rather let me ask you why I have never re∣ceived a line from you since you left the country?

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: To what end could my writing to you have served?

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: Oh! Flavia, I little thought, when we parted last, that the next time we met, I should find ou (so far from being mine) that you would be on the very point of becoming another's.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Can you blame me for my obedience to my father?

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: I am answer'd. I was told, before I came ere, indeed, that you were going to be disposed of ith your own consent. I must confess I was weak nough not to credit it; but that error of my judg∣ent being fully rectified, I shall take my leave, and rouble you no farther.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Stay—'tis true I have given my consent to a atch which (as you are informed, I suppose) with∣n these few hours is to be concluded; but if you ima∣ine I gave that consent in compliance with my own nclinations—

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: Can I imagine otherwise?

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: To do me justice you must—

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III.
DIV2.STAGE: WELLDON, FLAVIA, ROBIN.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Miss! Miss! here's your papa.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: My father!

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Come with me, Sir, and I'll put you into the back-garret.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Dear Weldon, there's my dressing-room; the boy will shew you a closet in it, where you may hide till we go into the next room, and then steal down unperceived.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: How can you make me such a cruel pro∣posal?

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Where's the cruelty of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: What! do you think I'll go tamely away and leave Shatterbrain to triumph? By Heaven I'll not—I'll stay and confront your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Pray pity me; I'm ready to die with appre∣hension.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: No, no, I'll stay I'm determined.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Avoid him but for this moment, and make your own conditions.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: By the lord Harry I hear him.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: Well, upon one proviso, dispose of me as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Name it.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: Swear that you will not marry Shatter∣brain to-night; swear to me that you will never bestow yourself on him, or any one else, without my previous approbation, and I'll go wherever you would have me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: I swear I never will, let what will be the consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: Enough—where shall I go?

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Follow me, Sir, and I'll shew you.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV2.STAGE: DOCTOR GRUEL, FLAVIA, and then ROBIN.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Flavia, child, I hear you have got company within; who are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Mrs. Junket and Miss Frolick, Sir, with two gentlemen I never saw before.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Impertinence! What brought them here? And was it not my positive commands—

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: They were told at the door, Sir, that we were not at home; but it seems they would take no denial.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Psha! What have you been doing in your young lady's dressing-room, sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: What shall I say, Miss?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: The oaf stares as if he had seen a ghost.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: I'm frighted out of my wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Why does he not answer me?

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Robin, why don't you answer my papa? What have you been doing in my dressing-room?

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Sure, Miss, you know very well what I have been doing there.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: If he discovers me, I am undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Is the rascal playing tricks? Speak, sirrah, or I'll make you.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: (turning to the door.) Pussy, pussy, pussy, pussy.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: What does the rascal mean by pussy, pussy?

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Why, Sir, I was looking for the—

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Get out of my sight,—How long has Mr. Shatterbrain been come?

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: I have heard nothing of him since, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Grant me patience! go desire one of the men to run to Mr. Shatterbrain's lodgings, and tell him we wait for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV2.STAGE: DOCTOR, GRUEL, FLAVIA, MRS. JUNKET, MISS FROLICK. SLANG, COXCOMB.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Oh, Doctor Gruel! I'm vastly glad you are come; I have been longing for you here, at such a rate—give me leave to present a couple of friends of mine to you—this is Captain Slang.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: I hope you're pretty well, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: This is Mr. Coxcomb.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: Sir, your most devoted.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: Doctor Gruel, how do you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: At your service, Madam—well, the familiar impudence of some people is astonishing!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: I believe you did not expect to find us here, did you?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: I cannot say, Madam, I expected to meet quite so much good company.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: Nay, we thought we should surprize you—but one of the drollest accidents has happen'd to us this afternoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: She's in earnest, Sir—we have had a hellish droll adventure, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Something so whimsical and out of the way, you'll die with laughing when you hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Then I don't desire to hear it at all, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Shatterbrain dined with us to day in the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Did he so—then, I suppose, it is to his in∣vitation, I am indebted for the honour of this visit.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: It is, and it is not owing to his invitation.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: Riddle me, riddle me ree.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: I don't understand you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: No!—Listen then, and you shall hear how that monster of rudeness served us—but here he comes to answer for himself.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE V.
DIV2.STAGE: DOCTOR GRUEL, SLANG, COXCOMB, MRS. JUNKET, MISS FROLICK, FLAVIA, and SHATTERBRAIN, who pops in and runs back again.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Mr. Shatterbrain, Mr. Shatterbrain, do we frighten you?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Cry you mercy—seeing so much company, I thought I had made a mistake again.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Again!

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Ay, Sir—I am just come from doing one of the cursedest things—the people will cer∣tainly think I was either mad, or drunk—but you must make my excuses.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: He takes no more notice of us, than if we were not in the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: To whom must I make your excuses, and what about?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Are you acquainted with the family at next door?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: They and I have liv'd upon the same steps these twenty years.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P:
I wish, with all my soul, you had liv'd twenty
leagues asunder—the damned fellows that brought me from my lodgings, not knowing your house, when they et me down, instead of knocking at this door, knock'd at that; to which when a servant came (who I after∣wards found thought me an apothecary) I made no more ado, but desired them to open the chair and walk'd in without any farther ceremony, taking it for granted I was here.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: You did not!

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: I did, upon my soul, Sir, and have made the strangest rout that ever you heard of; I went up stairs, where I found a chamber very elegantly furnish'd (so like this, in every particular egad, that I never once minded the difference) Well, Sir, there I sat, and sat, ex∣pecting every minute when I should see you come in; till at last my patience being quite exhausted—I ven∣tr▪d to open a door behind me, which lead into ano∣ther apartment.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Oh Lord! that was poor Mrs. Feebles; she has been bed rid a good while.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Pox on her—I had not got into the room two yards, before I stumbled over a stool; which roused the old Beldam, and she cryed out in a voice, be∣tween hoarse and squeeking—Who's there? to which I made no reply, for I began to suspect that I had com∣mitted some blunder. When putting her head out of the curtains, and perceiving, by the light of the fire, a person she did not know, she set up her pipes, and squalled to such a pitch, that the whole house was a∣bout us in an instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: And how did you get clear of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Why, after looking pretty much like a fool, as you may guess; I ask'd if that was not your house? To which being answered in the negative, I offer'd a thousand apologies; told them the plain truth; and one of the footmen luckily happening to know me, I march'd off with flying colours, a whole skin, and a tolerable good reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: When if they had been as well acquainted with you as I am, they would have suspected that you came with a villainous design against the old woman, and us'd you accordingly—Come, come, Mr. Shatterbrain, gentle∣men, don't steal into Ladies bed-chambers for nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: What, my fellow traveller! Mrs. Junket, Miss Frolick, Mr. Coxcomb!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: O! you have found us out at last!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: You are a very pretty gentleman, truly!

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: I hope you got safe to town, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter
SP.P: Very safe; but do you know, that I am be∣ginning to recollect, that I have been devilish rude to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: You are, are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Did not you ask me to sup with you some∣where to-night?

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: No, by the Lord; but you asked us.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Did I—Faith, I believe it was so; well, I beg your pardons; but you must forgive me this time, for you see I lay under an engagement, which I could not possibly postpone.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Shatterbrain, my daughter and I have some private business to transact; I expect my lawyer here every minute; and if you will step into the drawing-room, we'll do ourselves the plea∣sure to attend you there presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: Ay, ay, don't let us interrupt business.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: No ceremony, I beseech you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: Ladies, you'll shew us the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Good bye, Crazy (Slapping Shatterbrain on the back as she goes out)

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV2.STAGE: DOCTOR GRUEL, seeing the company to the Door, FLA∣VIA, SHATTERBRAIN, and ROBIN with a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Here's a letter, Sir, the gentleman's servant is below.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: A letter! give it me (taking the letter with∣out looking at the superscription, he opens and reads it to himself) bless my soul Doctor Gruel, here's a very odd thing; egad I don't know well what to make of it, but I believe I must go from you for a little while, for it seems to be on an affair of life and death.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Indeed, I am sorry to hear this; pray explain, what is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P:
Why, faith, that is what I would be glad to know myself, but, as I told you before, I don't very well understand—'Tis true, I am acquainted in my
Lord's family, but not very intimate, and they desire me here to come in all haste, for they are afraid he's in his last moments; What the devil can they want with me? I can be of no service to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Pr'ythee! Pr'ythee, let me look at it? Why this letter's to me, sirrah, how came you—

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Please your worship, I said it was for you, but the gentleman took it out of my hand. (Here Flavia flurting her fan, Shatterbrain takes it from her, in an absent fit, and begins to fiddle with it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: This is an exceeding unlucky affair? Is my Lord's servant below?

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Why did you say I was at home—tell him—

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: He says, if you don't come directly, my Lord will be dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Nay, then I must go—Well, my dear, Shat∣terbrain you'll entertain my daughter till I come back. Robin, set wine and glasses upon the table; it is but at the end of the street, and I shall be back in twenty minutes at farthest.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Pray offer no excuses.—but won't you take this along with you (offering him the fan.)

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: It is my daughter's I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: I beg ten thousand pardons—I hope Miss, I have not done it any mischief (giving it to her torn to pieces.)

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE VIII.
DIV2.STAGE: SHATTERBRAINN, FLAVIA, ROBIN, who sets wine upon the table, and afterwards WELLDON.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Madam, won't you chuse to be seated a chair (Robin places an armed chair which Shatterbrain sits down in himself: musing and laying one leg carelesly over the other, without taking any notice of Flavia. He pulls out his snuff-box spilling his snuff; takes a letter for his pocket handkerchief; then garters his stockings, &c.)

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: I am very oddly circumstanc'd here, however▪ I'll keep my word with Welldon, that I'm determin'd: but how to do it is the thing Mrs. Junket is a pure body in those cases, I'll e'en go and advise with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P:
(Not perceiving that Flavia has stolen off.) I'll assure you, Madam, it is with infinite satisfaction,
that I conclude this alliance with Doctor Gruel's family; and though I have not had an opportunity of paying my court to you, as much as you might expect, I am not less warm in my wishes, nor sincere in my attachment; nor have I the least doubt of our being as happy when married, as if my addresses had been longer: for a man, Madam, may make a very affectionate husband, with∣out having been a very violent lover: it indeed often happens, that the length of preliminaries weakens the vigour of the contract, and so—(turning about by de∣grees and looking all round the room) Miss—Miss Flavia; Hey day, gone, left me (tapping at the door where Well∣don is) where are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Here, here, (Welldon opens the door and Shat∣terbrain takes him by the hand without looking at him.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: You were gone before I miss'd you.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Shatterbrain, the devil (struggling to get loose)

SP.SPEAKER: Shatterbrain.
SP.P: Nay, I hold you now, and you shan't escape. Come sit down here, I must have a little serious conversation with you (seats him in the chair, and pulling another for himself perceives his mistake) Welldon!

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Plague on it.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Sure, I did not ask you to supper too.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Does he banter me.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IX.
DIV2.STAGE: SHATTERBRAIN, WELLDON, Mrs. JUNKET, Miss FROLICK, FLAVIA.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Defend me! What do I see?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Never mind (to Miss Frolick) do you draw off Shatterbrain.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Fro.
SP.P: I will if I can. Mr. Shatterbrain, you have had no tea this evening; if you will step into the next room, I will give you a cup.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: I shall be proud to receive any thing from your fair hands, Madam—Welldon I'm glad to see you. [Shatterbrain goes out with Miss Frolick, leaving Welldon, Flavia and Mrs. Junket on the Stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: How came this about, why did not you stay where you were?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: 'Sdeath, I'm in amaze, I thought you called me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Hold your confounded tongues; is it not time enough for you to squabble when you are man and wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Heaven knows when that will be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: If you follow my directions, I will put you in a method of bringing it about immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: My dear creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Hands off, none of your raptures, I be∣seech you. Is not the parson who is to marry you and Shatterbrain now in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Fla.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Who is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Fla.
SP.P: Supple, my Lord Courtland's chaplain.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: I think you said within that he and Shat∣terbrain were utter strangers.

SP.SPEAKER: Fla.
SP.P: I heard him ask my father yesterday what sort of a man Mr. Shatterbrain was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Does Supple, my Lord Courtland's chap∣lain know any thing of you?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: He never saw me in his life, I'm positive.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Then the business is done, if you will only take my advice, and have a little confidence. (A loud laugh without.) Bless me!

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Somebody is confoundedly tickled, but the jest moves this way.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE X.
DIV2.STAGE: Mrs. JUNKET, WELDON, FLAVIA, SLANG, COXCOMB.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: What's the cause of this immoderate mirth?

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: I can't tell you—ha! ha! ha!—Oh zounds?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: I hope you can speak, Mr. Coxcomb.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: Not I, by Gad, Madam, nor do I believe I shall ever be able to speak again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Let us leave these people to their laughing. I tell you once more I have a scheme in my head that must be attended with success, only do as I bid you: Billy, take her by the hand, and follow me down stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.P: Nay, but have a little patience, it is a matter of consequence, and should be weigh'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Weigh figs and raisins, it is an affair of consequence, and we have no time to weigh it. Billy, why don't you take her?

SP.SPEAKER: Well.
SP.P: Nay, my dear Flavia, don't hesitate; 'tis true indeed, we have no time to lose; she is our friend, and will consult both our interests.

SP.SPEAKER: Flav.
SP.P: Well do with me what you please.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XI.
DIV2.STAGE: COXCOMB, SHATTERBRAIN, MISS FROLICK and then MRS. JUNKET.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: Are you scalded?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: I believe I should if the tea had been hot enough; but, as it happens, I am come off pretty well, as to that particular. I am extremely sorry though that I was so unfortunate as to break the china bowl.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: What, in the name of vengeance, were you thinking of?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Why, I imagin'd there had been a chair behind me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: And how could you, heedless creature, go sit down without looking back.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Junk.
SP.P: Frolick, come hither, I have something to say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: Where are Flavia and Welldon?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Junk.
SP.P: Softly—Tacking together in the study.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick
SP.P: Tacking together.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Junk.
SP.P: Marrying—does that content you, I put them upon the project; the parson takes Welldon for Shatterbrain, and is now actually performing the ce∣remony.

SP.SPEAKER: Frolick.
SP.P: I don't believe it

SP.SPEAKER: Jun.
SP.P: Go, and convince yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: I will, if it be only to catch you in a fib.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XII.
DIV2.STAGE: SLANG, COXCOMB, SHATTERBRAIN, Mrs. JUNKET.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Shatterbrain, what was it you did just now, to make those creatures laugh so?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: A piece of my old giddiness; I had got a bowl of tea from Miss Frolick, and was going to sit down to drink it—but there being ne'er a chair behind me, souse I went to the bottom, and spilt the liquor over me, as you see.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Junk.
SP.P:
Thou wilt ever be a mad creature—Lord, I'm in a mighty joyous humour to-night, I wish we had fiddles here, I could dance from this, till six o'Clock to morrow morning. Tol lol lol. (Taking Coxcomb by the hand and dancing about the stage. Coxcomb, we'll positively come to your lodgings one
of these evenings, and you shall give us a dance, and a bit of supper. Tol de rol lol.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: (Taking a glass of wine) Mr. Shatterbrain here's to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Pretty well, I thank you, Sir, I hope you are very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Slan.
SP.P: Hey-day, cross purposes! Why zounds, man, I drink your health, I don't ask you how you do. You have been at Newmarket, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: You have a better opinion of me than I deserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: The devil, never at Newmarket!

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: There was excellent sport there last meeting, the Earl of Sweepstakes rid his own horse Fleabite, the best of three heats over the Beacon course for a thousand; I was within ten yards of him, when he came to the post. But it had like to have cost me dear, for I rid a damn'd skittish little jade, and striving to rein her back, she took head, and in spite of all I could do, run above a quarter of a mile with me—I was oblig'd to fling myself off at last, which I did—at the distance—Aye, by Gad, I am sure it was as far as from this to that there door.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Yes, I believe it might be there, or there∣abouts.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: Why you were not by?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: You were not by, I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: At what Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: Why, when my mare run away with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Your mare!

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: I'll be cursed if you know what I have been saying to you all this time.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Upon my word, Sir, not very well—but if you will be so good as to repeat it again, I'll take care to be more attentive.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XIII.
DIV2.STAGE: SLANG, COXCOMB, SHATTERBRAIN, Mrs. JUNKET, Miss FROLICK, and then DOCTOR GRUEL.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Well, did I tell you the truth or not?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Fro.
SP.P:
Yes but a truth that exceeds the example of romance. Why, 'tis over; they are as much one
as the church can make them: the Doctor is come home too Welldon has been a lucky fellow

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: I would say so if he had got the girl's fortune. Where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Fro.
SP.P: With Flavia, waiting their cue to appear—The Doctor will be up in a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Here he comes—Now for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor
SP.P: Your servant, good folks—Mr. Shatterbrain, what is this I hear? I am told you have stole a match on us. Did you think I had deserted you, or that I would go back of my engagements, which occasioned you to be in such a hurry?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Observe how Shatterbrain looks at him.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Do you direct your discourse to me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: I cannot say that ever I was much more astonished in my life. But for heaven's sake, my dear Shatterbrain, what unaccountable crotchet seiz'd you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Nay, there's no need of explanation—Only, I think, you might as well have stay'd till I came home, as have married my daughter in my absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: What's this!—Are you married Shatterbrain?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Not that I know of upon my soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Why, sure, Sir!—I'll take my oath it is not three minutes since Mr. Supple told me he had just married you and my daughter at your own requests.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Did Mr. Supple tell you so, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: I suppose you did not desire him to keep it a secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Not I, faith, Sir—for I never spoke a word to Mr. Supple since I was born.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Fro.
SP.P: Shatterbrain is in doubt whether he is married or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: I'll plague him—But, Mr. Shatterbrain, you had better recollect yourself a little upon this affair; perhaps you may have forgot.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Ay, Sir, recollect yourself; pray don't be positive.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I won't be positive—but you'll permit me to say, that, to the best of my knowledge. I am no more married to your daughter than I am to the empress of Russia.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Here is my daughter—I suppose, if it is so, she will remember it, tho' you can't.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XIV.
DIV2.STAGE: SHATTERBRAIN, Mrs. JUNKET, Miss FROLICK, SLANG, COXCOMB, Doctor GRUEL, FLAVIA, and afterwards WELLDON.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Flavia I hear you have been married since I went out, is it true?

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: There now, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Are you sure you have been married Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Very sure, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: What do you say to that, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Nothing, Sir, only it has escaped my me∣mory—that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Still in the same strain—Look'e, Mr. Shatterbrain, I have passed by a very singular piece of your behaviour to day already, imputing it to absence of mind, or I know not what; but this is too gross to be alledged to the same cause; 'tis a public affront both to me and my daughter, and as such I shall esteem it: however, to satisfy the company—who waits there—desire Mr. Supple to step up here.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Come back—I am indeed married.—

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: But not to Mr. Shatterbrain, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: I hope you are convinc'd now, Sir, that I was in the right—Damn it, I knew I could not be mi∣staken.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Dear Sir, pardon my first offence, and give us your blessing?

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: Now the murder's out.

SP.SPEAKER: Flavia.
SP.P: Can you refuse us your blessing, when we ask it on our knees?

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Pho, pho, stand up, I take it for granted your name is Welldon.

SP.SPEAKER: Welldon.
SP.P: That is my name, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Ungrateful girl—by what means have you carried on this intrigue? by what means brought it to this end? But don't give yourself the trouble to answer me, for I have done with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: Shatterbrain!

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Hah.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: What are you thinking of.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Upon my soul I cant say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: I never knew you otherwise: but pray rouse a litttle, you are a party concerned, here are a young couple in distress, aud they expect you will make use of your interest in their favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: That I will, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: I beg you may not, Sir, for the ill treatment you have met with, is one of my chiefest causes of anger.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Is it, why then to shew you that I don't harbour the least resentment upon that account; here, Mr. Welldon, take this young lady (giving him Doctor Gruels hand by mistake) whatever right and title I was like to have in her, I freely resign to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: Give you joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cox.
SP.P: Joy Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: This is very generous of you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: If you think so why don't you follow his example.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE XV.
DIV2.STAGE: SHATTERBRAIN, MRS. JUNKET, MISS FROLICK, SLANG, COXCOMB, DOCTOR GRUEL, FLAVIA, WELDON, ROBIN,

SP.SPEAKER: Robin.
SP.P: Mr. Shatterbrain, here's your servant has brought your gown and slippers.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Well, let him leave them.

SP.SPEAKER: Slang.
SP.P: Leave them, for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Pho, pho, I mean let him take them back again.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Frolick.
SP.P: Come, Doctor, wont you forgive them? I shant love you else.

SP.SPEAKER: Doctor.
SP.P: Well, Madam, 'tis more than they deserve, however, children, since it must be so, Heaven bless you, and make you happy together.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Jun.
SP.P: And now I think we have nothing to do, but go in and order supper as quick as possible; do, my dear Flavia, order supper as soon as you can, for I am starving with hunger.

SP.SPEAKER: Shatter.
SP.P: Ay! come, let's in to supper.
But hold—I had something or other to say,
"Kind ladies and gentlemen" how was it—stay.
Hiss our Farce, if you lik'd—hiss! No clap—marry rot it:
In short, guess my meaning, for I have forgot it.
